{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}} {{Use Australian English|date=July 2011}} {{Onesource|date=August 2009}} [[Image:ARC Centre for Complex Systems (logo).jpg|thumb|ACCS Logo]]
The '''ARC Centre for Complex Systems (ACCS''') was established in 2004 from a consortium of Australian universities, led by the [[University of Queensland]]. The objective of ACCS was to conduct basic and applied research in the field of [[complex systems]]. It conducted research into both the science and engineering of complex systems. Funding was provided by the [[Australian Research Council]] (ARC) and the universities involved. The ACCS was funded under the ARC's [[Center of excellence|Centre of Excellence]] Scheme <ref>[http://www.arc.gov.au/ncgp/ce/2003_coe_funding.htm ARC Centres of Excellence Scheme 2003] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090625030916/http://www.arc.gov.au/ncgp/ce/2003_coe_funding.htm |date=25 June 2009 }}</ref> until mid-2009, after which industry collaborations and further funding was established to continue to apply the Centre's research.
== Overview == [[Complex systems]] science is an emerging discipline developing new ways of investigating large, highly intricate, dynamically changing systems across diverse areas such as biology, social networks and socio-technological systems, economics and the environment. The ACCS was established to conduct world-class research on questions fundamental to understanding, designing and managing complex systems.
While complex systems research is considered basic research, with commercialisation still some time off, complex computing holds answers to real-life systems.<ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/news/technology/making-the-pace-in-a-hot-new-year/2006/01/30/1138469633668.html Making the pace in a hot new year], Beverley Head, theAge.com.au, Technology, 1 January 2006 </ref>
The ACCS provided a focus for complex systems science research in Australia, and developed strong infrastructure for modelling and analysing network-based systems, enabling the science to be applied to real-world problems.
The Centre had its headquarters at [[The University of Queensland]] in Brisbane, with nodes at [[Griffith University]] in Brisbane, [[Monash University]] in Melbourne, and [[The University of New South Wales]] campus at the [[Australian Defence Force Academy]] in Canberra.
The ACCS's research programs emphasised cross-disciplinary research, involving leading researchers from a range of disciplines including: systems and software engineering, economics, visualisation, human factors, computational mathematics and statistics, and relevant application domains including aerospace, economics, energy and biology.
== Research program == The goal of the ACCS's research was to develop deeper understanding of fundamental phenomena in complex systems, such as how macro-level system properties and behaviours emerge from relatively simple micro-level interactions, what mechanisms enable complex systems to self-organise, and how complex systems can be managed and controlled.
The [http://www.accs.uq.edu.au/research.html Centre's core research program] was based around a number of application areas.
=== Genetic regulatory networks=== Research in this program tackled fundamental questions about growth and form in cellular biology. Computational modelling was used to study how the control of development results from an interaction between each cell's genetic regulatory network and its inputs from neighbouring cells and its environment, and how the process proceeds reliably, while coping with unreliable components, perturbation, injury, and changing environments.
=== Air traffic control === This program applied complex systems science to the problem of improving the efficiency of air travel without compromising safety. To do this, researchers developed and used air traffic simulators to study new concepts and tools for air traffic management, and developed new approaches to assurance of system-level properties including safety and efficiency<ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/news/next/its-life-but-not-as-we-know-it/2005/11/28/1133026374254.html It's life, but not as we know it], Beverley Head, theAge.com.au, Technology, 29 November 2005 </ref>
=== Evolutionary economic systems=== In this program, complex systems and network theory was applied to economics and business to understand how evolutionary change occurs. Multi-agent modelling and associated simulation and calibration techniques were core components of the methodology used. We investigated new ways of testing for complex patterns in high frequency data, by studying trade-by trade data in stock markets and in electricity markets and seeking 'pattern matches' in artificially generated agent-based modelling data. We investigated new ways of dealing with spatial complexity in several contexts. Also visualisation techniques, rarely used in economics, were applied in a range of data-rich contexts to better understand the architecture and complex dynamics of systems.
=== Electricity networks and energy markets=== This program investigated ways of integrating technical and market aspects of power systems with price dynamics to provide key insights into planning expansion of Australia's power transmission network. It also aimed to apply modern computational modelling techniques to the interface between the physical properties of the electricity system and its economic considerations. A particular focus was placed on the impacts of the transmission network and power station operation on electricity price behaviour and its influence on infrastructure investment decisions. It also looked into the importance of customer-load impact on system and market operations.
=== Dependable computer-based systems=== This program was concerned with the development of modelling and analysis tools to ensure that dependability is designed into complex computer-based systems, particularly in areas such as transport, health and finance. There is a constant need for new methods and tools to enable engineers to ensure that such systems meet society's demands for dependability, safety and reliability. One of the tools, Behavior Trees, was successfully trialled by Raytheon Australia to analyse six large defence projects.<ref> [http://www.raytheon.com.au/Default.aspx?x=501 Raytheon Australia supports pioneering systems research] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090915050723/http://www.raytheon.com.au/Default.aspx?x=501 |date=15 September 2009 }}, Raytheon News Release, 3 September 2008 </ref><ref>Finding a simple solution to complex systems, David Binning, [http://www.afr.com/home/The Australian Financial Review], 9 October 2008, p7 Project Management Special Report </ref>
=== Complex systems theory and applications === In addition to the research programs described above, the ACCS included a number of projects addressing key problems for complex systems. The projects were concerned with the application of theory to solve issues in the design and operation of complex socio-technological systems, and with the development of new analysis techniques for complex systems.<ref> [http://www.calit2.net/newsroom/article.php?id=1483 Cyberinfrastructure expert spells out cooperation Between US and Australia], Tiffany Fox, Calit2 Newsroom Web article, 5 March 2009.</ref>
== See also == * [[Behavior Trees]] * [[Complexity economics]] * [[Air traffic control]] * [[Genetic regulatory network]]
==References== <references />
== External links == * [http://www.accs.uq.edu.au ARC Centre for Complex Systems] ACCS Website. * [http://www.accs.uq.edu.au/research.html ACCS research program] link provides access to project details and outcomes, including publications * [http://vlab.infotech.monash.edu.au/ VLAB. ] Monash University’s Complexity Virtual Lab * [http://www.abc.net.au/rn/scienceshow/stories/2007/1968449.htm The Growth in Air Traffic], ACCS Director, Peter Lindsay's interview with Robin Williams, ABC Radio's Science Show, 7 July 2007

{{Infobox website |name = Arca-Net |url = [http://www.arca-net.info/ www.arca-net.info] |type = Travel guide to old [[livestock]] breeds and rare plants |language = [[English language|English]], [[German language|German]], [[French language|French]], [[Italian language|Italian]] |owner = [[SAVE Foundation]] |launch date = 2005 |current status = Online }}'''
Arca-Net is a European Ark-network of institutions that keep endangered [[livestock]] breeds or rare cultivated plants, making them known to the public. Arca-Net is designed for a broad public and in form of a virtual guide, at any time available via Internet. Descriptions of the institutions, directions on getting there, offers and information on the [[livestock]] breeds kept and plants cultivated, their distribution, status of endangering and their history are available from Arca-Net.<ref>[http://ictupdate.cta.int/en/Links/Web-Resources/Arca-Net2 Issue 53: Farmer services [[ICT update]]]</ref>
== Background == Rare and endangered livestock breeds and old cultivated plants have largely disappeared from agricultural production units but they continue to live on numerous Ark-farms, livestock parks, variety gardens, [[open-air museums]] and other institutions. Arca-Net is unique collection of establishments conserving the traditional breeds of their region<ref>[http://www.ela-europe.org/read/Latest%20news/ELBARN European Livestock Association/ELBARN] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726020733/http://www.ela-europe.org/read/Latest%20news/ELBARN |date=July 26, 2011 }}</ref> and makes these institutions known and initiates visits.<ref>[http://www.ethicalsurfing.com/eng/Map-the-territory/Agriturismo-Capra-Matilda Ethical Sufring-Agriturismo Capra Matilda]</ref> Moreover, Arca-Net offers easily understandable background information and raises about the topic of [[agrobiodiversity]].<ref>[http://www.save-foundation.net/english/PDF/Arca-Net_overview.pdf Arca-Net overview (PDF)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724054527/http://www.save-foundation.net/english/PDF/Arca-Net_overview.pdf |date=July 24, 2011 }}</ref>
Within the framework of the Ark- and Rescue centre census for rare and endangered breeds in Europe, the [[SAVE Foundation]] developed the information portal Arca-Net.<ref>http://www.arca-net.info/pages/frame.asp?sprache=en</ref> Over 570 institutions in 46 [[List of sovereign states and dependent territories in Europe|European Countries]] (2010) are enlisted in Arca-Net. All of these facilities offer access to their [[livestock]] animals and cultivated plants such as [[fruit]] and [[vegetables]].
== Layout == The different institutions are presented, details for a visit described, directions explained and breed descriptions to many livestock breeds are given.<ref>[https://archive.is/20120905152237/http://www.organic-market.info/web/News_in_brief/Other_Topics/Arca-Net/176/200/0/8284.html Organic-Market.info 2010-08-09]</ref> Updates and new entries are processed by the institutions themselves via password protected user accounts. Arca-Net is a Europe-wide network that is constantly expanding.
On the search site users can search for [[livestock]] breeds, cultivated plants, countries, kind of institutions and products. The search results are either listed or displayed on a map. The Ark station map with all the locations and categories of the centres makes searching in specific regions or countries in Europe easy.<ref>[http://www.clubofrome.at/varieties/news.html News June 2010 [[Club of Rome]]]</ref> After selecting an institution further background information such as the complete address, animals kept, directions, opening hours, entrance fees, products for sale etc. are shown.
== Guidelines == Conditions for gathering data on suitable establishments for the European Network Arca-Net<ref>[http://www.arca-net.info/pages/pdf/Arca-Net_Guidelines.pdf Arca-Net Guidelines]</ref>
=== Basic conditions ===
==== Obligatory conditions ==== * Collection or permanent exhibition of rare livestock breeds or varieties of cultivated plant open to the public (also viewing by arrangement only) * Pedigree breeding with participation in a breeding program. Animals must be kept in such a way that the welfare of the animal is respected
==== Desirable conditions ==== * Establishment recognised by the national organisation (e.g. GEH’s Arche-Höfe, RBST’s Approved Farm Parks) or a city-farm, open-air museum, eco-museum, nature park centre (with membership of relevant professional association) * The differing characteristics of the breeds and varieties should be documented (using information boards, labels or numbered to use in reference with a brochure) * It is possible to also include interesting processing points which use traditional means to manufacture and market products from traditional breeds and varieties
=== Plants === * It must be a collection of, at least, regional importance * Or an important cross-section of one species (e.g. Limonaio, Olivaio)
=== Animals === * Breeding groups from at least three species from two size categories (see below) * Or an important breeding station/stud of only one breed if this establishment has a significant part of the breed * Or an important cross-section of one species, e.g. Donkey farm with national breeds
=== Processing point === * Processing point open to the public (e.g. wool workshop, mill) which uses traditional and complete production methods and also declares the products accordingly
== External links == * http://www.arca-net.info/
== References == <references />

{{Infobox organization |name =Austrian Ludwig Wittgenstein Society |image = Logo_for_the_Austrian_Ludwig_Wittgenstein_Society.jpg |size = 162px |alt = Pencil on board |caption = |map = |msize = |malt = |mcaption = |abbreviation = ALWS |motto = |predecessor = |successor = |formation = 1974 |extinction = |type = |status = |purpose = Research and Education |headquarters = |location = [[Kirchberg am Wechsel]] |coords = {{coord|47|37|N|16|0|E|region:AT_type:edu|display=inline,title}} |region_served = |membership = Open to scholars and students |language = German and English |general = Dr. Volker Munz |leader_title = President |leader_name = Professor Christian Kanzian |key_people = |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = [[Institute Vienna Circle]]{{cite web|title=Institute Vienna Circle|url=http://www.univie.ac.at/ivc/}}
Die Internationale Ludwig Wittgenstein Gesellschaft{{cite web|title=Die Internationale Ludwig Wittgenstein Gesellschaft|url=http://www.ilwg.eu}}
Österreichische Gesellschaft für Philosophie{{cite web|title=Österreichische Gesellschaft für Philosophie|url=http://oegp.org/en/}} |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.alws.at www.alws.at] |remarks = |former name = }} The '''Austrian Ludwig Wittgenstein Society''' was first established in 1974 to promote philosophical conferences, workshops, summer schools, and research that are inspired by the work of [[Ludwig Wittgenstein]] and the [[Vienna Circle]].{{cite web|title=Graz: Austrian Ludwig Wittgenstein Society |url=http://philosophie-gewi.uni-graz.at/en/researching/philosophical-societies/oesterreichische-ludwig-wittgenstein-gesellschaft/ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303224042/http://philosophie-gewi.uni-graz.at/en/researching/philosophical-societies/oesterreichische-ludwig-wittgenstein-gesellschaft/ |archivedate=2016-03-03 }}{{cite web|title=Austrian Ludwig Wittgenstein Society|url=http://www.alws.at}} It is an international society, which also has a publication series.{{cite web|title=Publications of the Austrian Ludwig Wittgenstein Society|url=http://www.ontos-verlag.de/index.php?option=com_virtuemart&page=shop.browse&category_id=21&Itemid=1}} ==History== In 1974, [[Elisabeth Leinfellner]], [[Werner Leinfellner]], Rudolf Haller, Paul Weingartner, and Adolf Hübner founded the Austrian Ludwig Wittgenstein Society (ALWS), but it was the impetus of the first [[International Wittgenstein Symposium]] in [[Kirchberg am Wechsel]], [[Lower Austria]] that led to its development as an international society. The location of the ALWS is in Kirchberg am Wechsel and the location was selected because Ludwig Wittgenstein taught at elementary schools close Kirchberg am Wechsel in the 1920s. ==Goals== The ALWS has two primary goals. *To promote the analysis, tradition, and dissemination of Wittgenstein’s philosophy. *To promote, more generally, philosophy that has its roots in Austria and other countries with emphasis on [[analytic philosophy]] inspired by Wittgenstein and [[philosophy of science]] inspired by, but not limited to, the philosophy of the Vienna Circle.{{cite web|title=Goals|url=http://www.alws.at/index.php/alws/view/unsere_ziele/}} ==Membership== They currently report 120 members both national and international. Individuals can download an application form their website. Membership is decided by the Executive Committee of the ALWS based on academic criteria. Students pay half the fee. Members receive a 30% discount on fees for the International Wittgenstein Symposium and for ALWS publications.{{cite web|title=Membership|url=http://www.alws.at/index.php/alws/view/mitgliedschaft/}} ==Publications== Since the first International Wittgenstein Symposium, the ALWS has published its proceedings. In 2006, they started a new series (published by ontos verlag). The new series contains: *The official proceedings of the International Wittgenstein Symposium *Special workshops *High-quality publications submitted to and reviewed by the ALWS. ==International Ludwig Wittgenstein Institute (ILWI)== The ILWI was recently founded by the ALWS and supports scientific and cultural projects that are related to Wittgenstein’s philosophy and the goals of the ALWS. The ILWI presents:{{cite web|title=ILWI|url=http://www.alws.at/index.php/ilwi/view/ilwi_general_information/}} *Workshops *Summer schools *Wittgenstein lectures *Research opportunities at the ILWI ==Sponsorship== The Austrian Ludwig Wittgenstein Society is funded by the government of [[Lower Austria]], the Austrian Federal Ministry for Science and Research, Austrian National Bank, Raiffeisenbank NÖ-Süd Alpin, Kirchberg am Wechsel, membership fees, and donations.{{cite web|title=Sponsors|url=http://www.alws.at/index.php/credit/view/sponsoren/}} ==See also== *[[Ludwig Wittgenstein]] *[[International Wittgenstein Symposium]] *[[Haus Wittgenstein]] *[[Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus]] *[[Philosophical Investigations]] *[[On Certainty]] ==References== ==External links== *[http://www.alws.at Austrian Ludwig Wittgenstein Society] *[http://www.britishwittgensteinsociety.herts.ac.uk British Wittgenstein Society] *[http://www.britishwittgensteinsociety.herts.ac.uk Nordic Wittgenstein Society] {{Ludwig Wittgenstein|state=uncollapsed}} {{analytic philosophy}} {{philosophy of language}} {{Philosophy of mind}} {{Philosophy of science}} {{logic}} {{metaphysics}} {{epistemology}} [[Category:Ludwig Wittgenstein]] [[Category:Philosophical societies]] [[Category:Philosophy of science]] [[Category:Analytic philosophy]] [[Category:Philosophy of mind]] [[Category:Philosophy of language]] [[Category:Logic]] [[Category:Metaphysics]] [[Category:Epistemology]]

{{infobox biodatabase |title = The BRENDA Tissue Ontology (BTO) |logo =[[File:Database.png]] |description = ontology of all organisms for [[enzyme]] sources. |scope = |organism = |center = |laboratory = |author = |pmid = 21030441 |released = 2003 |standard = |format = |url = http://www.brenda-enzymes.org/ontology.php?ontology_id=3 |download = |webservice = |sql = |sparql = |webapp = |standalone = |license = |versioning = |frequency = |curation = |bookmark = |version= }}
The '''BTO'''<ref name="Gremse2011">Gremse, M., Chang, A., Schomburg, I., Grote, A., Scheer, M., Ebeling, C., Schomburg, D. (2011): „[http://nar.oxfordjournals.org/content/39/suppl_1/D507.long The BRENDA Tissue Ontology (BTO): the first all-integrating ontology of all organisms for enzyme sources]“, ''Nucleic Acids Res.'', 39 (Database issue): D507–D513</ref> ('''B'''RENDA '''T'''issue '''O'''ntology) represents a comprehensive structured [[encyclopedia]]. It provides terms, classifications, and definitions of [[tissue (biology)|tissues]], [[organ (anatomy)|organs]], anatomical structures, plant parts, [[cell culture]]s, [[cell type]]s, and [[cell culture|cell lines]] of organisms from all taxonomic groups ([[animal]]s, [[plant]]s, [[fungus|fungis]], [[protozoa|protozoon]]) as enzyme sources. The information is connected to the functional data in the [[BRENDA]] ("BRaunschweig ENzyme DAtabase“)<ref name="Schomburg20132">Schomburg, I., Chang, A., Placzek, S., Söhngen, C., Rother. M., Lang, M., Munaretto, C., Ulas, S., Stelzer, M., Grote, A., Scheer, M., Schomburg, D. (2013): „[http://nar.oxfordjournals.org/content/41/D1/D764.long BRENDA in 2013: integrated reactions, kinetic data, enzyme function data, improved disease classification: new options and contents in BRENDA]“, ''Nucleic Acids Res.'', 41 (Database issue): D764–D772</ref> [[enzyme]] information system.
BTO is one of the first tissue-specific [[ontology|ontologies]] in [[life sciences]], not restricted to a specific organism or a specific organism group providing a user-friendly access to the wide range of tissue and cell-type information. Databases, such as ''Ontology Lookup Service'' or ses, such as ''[[MIRIAM Registry]]'' or of the [[European Bioinformatics Institute|EBI-EMBL]], the ''TissueDistributionDB'', including the ''Tissue Synonym Library'' of the [[German Cancer Research Center]] (DKFZ) in Heidelberg or the ''Bioportal'' plattform of the [[National Center for Biomedical Ontology]] in Stanford, USA rely on BTO and implement the encyclopedia as an essential repository of information into their respective plattform.
BTO enables users from [[medical research]] and [[pharmaceutical sciences]] to search for the occurrence and [[histology|histological]] detection of disease-related enzymes in tissues, which play an important role in [[diagnosis]], therapies, and [[drug development]]. In [[biochemistry]] and [[biotechnology]] the organism-specific tissue terms linked to enzyme functional data are an important resource for the understanding of the metabolism and regulation in life sciences. Ontologies represent classification systems that provide controlled and structured vocabularies.<ref name="Schomburg2014">Schomburg, I., Chang, A., Schomburg, D. (2014): „[http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2213020914000032 Standardization in enzymology—Data integration in the world’s enzyme information system BRENDA]“, ''Perspectives in Science'', 1: 15–23</ref> They are important tools to illustrate and to link evolutionary correlations.
Development of BTO started in 2003, aimed to connect the biochemical and molecular biological enzyme data of BRENDA with a hierarchical and standardized collection of tissue-specific terms. The functional enzyme data and information in BRENDA have been manually annotated and structured by experts from biochemistry, biology, and chemistry. By August 2014, the BTO contained over 5,500 terms, linked to 4,000 synonyms and 4,500 definitions. The terms are classified under generic categories, rules, and formats of the Gene Ontology Consortium (GO,<ref name="Roncaglia2013">Roncaglia, P., Martone, M.E., Hill, D.P., Berardini, T.Z., Foulger, R.E., Imam, F.T., Drabkin, H., Mungall, C.J., Lomax, J. (2013): „[http://www.jbiomedsem.com/content/4/1/20 The Gene Ontology (GO) Cellular Component Ontology: integration with SAO (Subcellular Anatomy Ontology) and other recent developments]“, ''J. Biomed. Semantics'', 4: 20</ref>), organized as a [[Directed acyclic graph|directed acyclic graph (DAG)]] created using the [[Open-source software|open-source]] OBO-Edit.<ref name="Smith2010">Smith, B., Ashburner, M., Rosse, C., Bard, J., Bug, W., Ceusters, W., Goldberg, L.J., Eilbeck, K., Ireland, A., Mungall, C.J.; OBI Consortium, Leontis, N., Rocca-Serra, P., Ruttenberg, A., Sansone, S.A., Scheuermann, R.H., Shah, N., Whetzel,P.L,, Lewis, S. (2010): „[http://www.nature.com/nbt/journal/v25/n11/full/nbt1346.html The OBO Foundry: coordinated evolution of ontologies to support biomedical data integration]“, ''Nat. Biotechnol.'', 25: 1251–1255</ref> All terms from each level are directly connected the enzyme data in BRENDA. BTO is a suitable tool to distinguish between different enzymes which are expressed in a tissue-specific manner.
== Content and Features ==
BTO draws upon the comprehensive enzyme specific data of the BRENDA enzyme information system. Presently (August 2014) 90,500 enzyme-organism-tissue specific data from more than 11,000 proteins are stored in BRENDA. These entries were manually annotated from more thant 135,000 different literature references. All terms in BTO are evaluated and classified according to the OBO-format, and are connected by specific relationships. Each term is a distinct entry within the ontology and is automatically assigned to a unique BTO-identifier (BTO-ID). The BTO-IDs serve as stable accession numbers in order to create cross-references to further external biochemical databases. Further tissue und cell-type specific terms from external databases (i.e. [[UniProt]]) are integrated into BTO.
The terms are classified in 4 main categories (subgraphs):
* animal * plant * fungus * other sources
Further levels are defined below the main categories (=nodes), classifiying the “parent”, “child”, and “grandchild” all connected via specific relationships (=edges)
* is_a (e.g. skeletal muscle fibre is_a muscle fibre) * part_of (e.g. muscle fibre part_of muscle) * develops/derives_from (e.g.myoma cell develops/derives_from muscle fibre) * related_to (description of more general relationships between terms which are not covered by the other ones)
Most of the terms are clearly associated with specific organisms, organs, tissues, or cell types. However, there are several identical designations for tissues both in plants and animals, e.g. “epidermis”. To distinguish between those tissue terms and to classify them correctly into BTO for plant tissues the prefix “plant” is placed before the term, e.g. “plant epidermis”.
More than 80% of the tissue terms have definitions that describe the meaning and context. These definitions are obtained from i.e. medical dictionaries and cell line databases ([[Merriam-Webster’s Collegiate Dictionary|Webster’s Dictionary]], [[Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen und Zellkulturen|DSMZ]]).
== Availability ==
The entries in BTO are updated bi-annually as part of the major update of BRENDA. It is available via the BRENDA website in the category “Ontology Explorer”. The enzyme source terms can be searched via the BTO query form. As a result, the user receives a list of EC numbers which are directly connected to the enzyme information of BRENDA. It is also possible to search via the BRENDA “Source Tissue” search form (“Classic View”). The result page displays all enzymes which are isolated or detected in the searched tissue term, directly linked to BTO.
BTO and BRENDA are freely accessible for academic users. It can be freely downloaded via the “Ontology Explorer” of the BRENDA website or in the OBO format from “Obofoundry”. Commercial users require a license distributed by the ''biobase GmbH''.
== Literature References == <references />
== Links == * [http://www.brenda-enzymes.org/ontology.php BRENDA Ontology Explorer] * [http://www.brenda-enzymes.org/ official BRENDA website] * [http://www.enzyme-database.org/index.php ExplorEnz – Enzyme Nomenclature] * [http://www.biobase-international.com/product/brenda distribution of BRENDA licences] * [http://www.obofoundry.org/cgi-bin/detail.cgi?id=brenda download page at Obofoundry] * [http://geneontology.org/ Gene Ontology Consortium] * [http://www.ebi.ac.uk/ontology-lookup/browse.do?ontName=BTO Ontology Lookup Service of EBI-EMBL] * [http://bioportal.bioontology.org/ontologies/BTO Bioportal of the National Center for Biomedical Ontology, Stanford, USA]

{{short description|The reworking of soils and sediments by animals or plants}} '''Bioturbation''' is defined as the reworking of [[soil]]s and [[sediment]]s by animals or plants. These include burrowing, ingestion and defecation of sediment grains. Bioturbating activities have a profound effect on the environment and <ref name=":10" /> are thought to be a primary driver of [[biodiversity]].<ref name=":18" /> The formal study of bioturbation began in the 1800s by [[Charles Darwin]] experimenting in his garden.<ref name=":18" /> The disruption of aquatic sediments and terrestrial soils through bioturbating activities provides significant [[ecosystem services]]. These include the alteration of [[nutrient]]s in aquatic sediment and overlying water, shelter to other species in the form of burrows in terrestrial and water ecosystems, and soil production on land.<ref name="shaler1891">Shaler, N. S., 1891, The origin and nature of soils, in Powell, J. W., ed., USGS 12th Annual report 1890-1891: Washington, D.C., Government Printing Office, p. 213-45.</ref><ref name=":30" />
Bioturbators are deemed [[ecosystem engineer]]s because they alter resource availability to other species through the physical changes they make to their environments.<ref name=":30" /> This type of ecosystem change affects the evolution of cohabitating species and the environment,<ref name=":30" /> which is evident in [[trace fossil]]s left in marine and terrestrial sediments. Other bioturbation effects include altering the texture of sediments [[diagenesis|(diagenesis]]), [[bioirrigation]], and displacement of microorganisms and non-living particles. Bioturbation is sometimes confused with the process of bioirrigation, however these processes differ in what they are mixing; bioirrigation refers to the mixing of water and solutes in sediments and is an effect of bioturbation.<ref name=":18" /> [[File:Walrus (Odobenus rosmarus) resting in a crowd on Wahlbergøya, Svalbard (3).jpg|alt=Walrus|thumb|A walrus (''Odobenus rosmarus'') in a pod on Wahlberøya in Hinlopenstrait, Svalbard. Note the sediment on its left tusk.]] [[Walrus]]es, [[salmon]], and [[pocket gophers]] are examples of large bioturbators.<ref name=":12">Humphreys, G. S., and Mitchell, P. B., 1983, A preliminary assessment of the role of bioturbation and rainwash on sandstone hillslopes in the Sydney Basin, in Australian and New Zealand Geomorphology Group, p. 66-80.</ref><ref name=":21">{{Cite journal|last=Pillay|first=D|date=2010-06-23|title=Expanding the envelope: linking invertebrate bioturbators with micro-evolutionary change|url=http://www.int-res.com/abstracts/meps/v409/p301-303/|journal=Marine Ecology Progress Series|language=en|volume=409|pages=301–303|doi=10.3354/meps08628|issn=0171-8630|bibcode=2010MEPS..409..301P}}</ref><ref name=":26" /> Although the activities of these large macrofaunal bioturbators are more conspicuous, the dominant bioturbators are small invertebrates, such as [[earthworm]]s, [[polychaete]]s, [[Thalassinidea|ghost shrimp]], mud shrimp, and [[Chironomidae|midge larvae]].<ref name=":18" /><ref name=":23" /> The activities of these small invertebrates, which include burrowing and ingestion and defecation of sediment grains, contribute to mixing and the alteration of sediment structure.
== History of the Study of Bioturbation == Bioturbation's importance for soil processes and [[geomorphology]] was ﬁrst realized by Charles Darwin, who devoted his last scientific book to the subject (''[[The Formation of Vegetable Mould through the Action of Worms]]'').<ref name=":10" /> Darwin spread chalk dust over a field to observe changes in the depth of the chalk layer over time.<ref name=":10" /> Excavations 30 years after the initial deposit of chalk revealed that the chalk was buried 18 centimeters under the sediment, which indicated a burial rate of 6 millimeters per year.<ref name=":10" /> Darwin attributed this burial to the activity of earthworms in the sediment and determined that these disruptions were important in soil formation.<ref name=":10" /><ref name=":18">{{Cite journal|last=Wilkinson|first=Marshall T.|last2=Richards|first2=Paul J.|last3=Humphreys|first3=Geoff S.|date=2009-12-01|title=Breaking ground: Pedological, geological, and ecological implications of soil bioturbation|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0012825209001470|journal=Earth-Science Reviews|volume=97|issue=1|pages=257–272|doi=10.1016/j.earscirev.2009.09.005|bibcode=2009ESRv...97..257W}}</ref> In 1891, geologist [[Nathaniel Shaler]] expanded Darwin's concept to include soil disruption by ants and trees.<ref name=":18" /><ref name="shaler1891" /> The term "bioturbation" was later coined by Rudolf Richter in 1952 to describe structures in sediment caused by living organisms.<ref name=":30">{{Cite journal|last=Kristensen|first=E|last2=Penha-Lopes|first2=G|last3=Delefosse|first3=M|last4=Valdemarsen|first4=T|last5=Quintana|first5=CO|last6=Banta|first6=GT|date=2012-02-02|title=What is bioturbation? The need for a precise definition for fauna in aquatic sciences|url=http://www.int-res.com/abstracts/meps/v446/p285-302/|journal=Marine Ecology Progress Series|language=en|volume=446|pages=285–302|doi=10.3354/meps09506|issn=0171-8630|bibcode=2012MEPS..446..285K}}</ref> Since the 1980s, the term "bioturbation" has been widely used in soil and geomorphology literature to describe the reworking of soil and sediment by plants and animals.<ref name=":12" />
== Evolution and Ecology ==
=== Evolution === The onset of bioturbation had a profound effect on the environment and the evolution of other organisms.<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=Meysman|first=F|last2=Meddelburg|first2=J|last3=Heip|first3=C|date=|title=Bioturbation: a fresh look at Darwin's last idea|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0169534706002436|journal=Trends in Ecology & Evolution|volume=21|issue=12|pages=688–695|doi=10.1016/j.tree.2006.08.002|via=|year=2006}}</ref> Bioturbation is thought to have been an important co-factor of the [[Cambrian explosion|Cambrian Explosion]], during which most major animal [[Phylum|phyla]] appeared in the fossil record over a short time.<ref name=":10" /> [[Predation]] arose during this time and promoted the development of hard skeletons, for example bristles, spines, and shells, as a form of [[armored]] protection.<ref name=":10" /> It is hypothesized that bioturbation resulted from this skeleton formation.<ref name=":10" /> These new hard parts enabled animals to dig into the sediment to seek shelter from predators, which created an incentive for predators to search for prey in the sediment (see [[Evolutionary arms race|Evolutionary Arms Race]]).<ref name=":10" /> Burrowing species fed on buried organic matter in the sediment which resulted in the evolution of deposit feeding (consumption of organic matter within sediment).<ref name=":10" /> Prior to the development of bioturbation, laminated [[microbial mat]]s were the dominant biological structures of the ocean floor and drove much of the [[Ecosystem|ecosystem functions]].<ref name=":10" /> As bioturbation increased, burrowing animals disturbed the microbial mat system and created a mixed sediment layer with greater biological and chemical diversity.<ref name=":10" /> This greater biological and chemical diversity is thought to have led to the evolution and diversification of seafloor-dwelling species.<ref name=":10" /><ref name=":21" />
An alternate, less widely accepted hypothesis for the origin of bioturbation exists. The [[trace fossil]] ''Nenoxites'' is thought to be the earliest record of bioturbation, predating the Cambrian Period.<ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|last=Rogov|first=Vladimir|last2=Marusin|first2=Vasiliy|last3=Bykova|first3=Natalia|last4=Goy|first4=Yuriy|last5=Nagovitsin|first5=Konstantin|last6=Kochnev|first6=Boris|last7=Karlova|first7=Galina|last8=Grazhdankin|first8=Dmitriy|date=2012-05-01|title=The oldest evidence of bioturbation on Earth|url=http://pubs.geoscienceworld.org/geology/article/40/5/395/130862/The-oldest-evidence-of-bioturbation-on-Earth|journal=Geology|language=en|volume=40|issue=5|pages=395–398|doi=10.1130/g32807.1|issn=0091-7613|bibcode=2012Geo....40..395R}}</ref> The fossil is dated to 555 million years, which places it in the [[Ediacaran|Ediacaran Period.]]<ref name=":11" /> The fossil indicates a 5 centimeter depth of bioturbation in muddy sediments by a burrowing worm.<ref name=":11" /> This is consistent with food-seeking behavior, as there tended to be more food resources in the mud than the water column.<ref name=":31">{{Cite journal|last=Gingras|first=Murray|last2=Hagadorn|first2=James W.|last3=Seilacher|first3=Adolf|last4=Lalonde|first4=Stefan V.|last5=Pecoits|first5=Ernesto|last6=Petrash|first6=Daniel|last7=Konhauser|first7=Kurt O.|date=2011-05-15|title=Possible evolution of mobile animals in association with microbial mats|url=http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/ngeo1142|journal=Nature Geoscience|language=en|volume=4|issue=6|pages=372–375|doi=10.1038/ngeo1142|issn=1752-0908|bibcode=2011NatGe...4..372G}}</ref> However, this hypothesis requires more precise [[Geochronology|geological dating]] to rule out an early Cambrian origin for this specimen.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brasier|first=Martin D.|last2=McIlroy|first2=Duncan|last3=Liu|first3=Alexander G.|last4=Antcliffe|first4=Jonathan B.|last5=Menon|first5=Latha R.|title=The oldest evidence of bioturbation on Earth: COMMENT|url=http://mr.crossref.org/iPage?doi=10.1130%2FG33606C.1|journal=Geology|volume=41|issue=5|pages=e289–e289|doi=10.1130/g33606c.1|year=2013|bibcode=2013Geo....41E.289B}}</ref>
The evolution of trees during the [[Devonian|Devonian Period]] enhanced soil weathering and increased the spread of soil due to bioturbation by tree roots.<ref name=":20">{{Cite journal|last=Algeo|first=Thomas J.|last2=Scheckler|first2=Stephen E.|date=1998-01-29|title=Terrestrial-marine teleconnections in the Devonian: links between the evolution of land plants, weathering processes, and marine anoxic events|url=http://rstb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/353/1365/113|journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London B: Biological Sciences|language=en|volume=353|issue=1365|pages=113–130|doi=10.1098/rstb.1998.0195|issn=0962-8436|pmc=1692181}}</ref> Root penetration and uprooting also enhanced soil carbon storage by enabling mineral weathering and the burial of organic matter.<ref name=":20" />
=== Ecosystem function === ==== Functional Groupings ==== Bioturbators have been organized by a variety of functional groupings based on either ecological characteristics or biogeochemical effects.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Michaud|first=Emma|last2=Desrosiers|first2=Gaston|last3=Mermillod-Blondin|first3=Florian|last4=Sundby|first4=Bjorn|last5=Stora|first5=Georges|date=2006-10-03|title=The functional group approach to bioturbation: II. The effects of the Macoma balthica community on fluxes of nutrients and dissolved organic carbon across the sediment–water interface|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022098106003558|journal=Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology|volume=337|issue=2|pages=178–189|doi=10.1016/j.jembe.2006.06.025}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Weinberg|first=James R.|date=1984-08-28|title=Interactions between functional groups in soft-substrata: Do species differences matter?|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0022098184900911|journal=Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology|volume=80|issue=1|pages=11–28|doi=10.1016/0022-0981(84)90091-1}}</ref> While the prevailing categorization is based on the way bioturbators transport and interact with sediments, the various groupings likely stem from the relevance of a categorization mode to a field of study (such as ecology or sediment biogeochemistry) and an attempt to concisely organize the wide variety of bioturbating organisms in classes that describe their function. Examples of categorizations include those based on feeding and motility,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fauchald|first=K|last2=Jumars|first2=P|date=1979|title=Diet of worms: a study of polychaete feeding guilds|url=|journal=Oceanography and Marine Biology|volume=17|pages=|via=}}</ref> feeding and biological interactions,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Josefson|first=Alf B.|date=1985-12-30|title=Distribution of diversity and functional groups of marine benthic infauna in the Skagerrak (eastern North Sea) - Can larval availability affect diversity?|url=https://doi.org/10.1080/00364827.1985.10419680|journal=Sarsia|volume=70|issue=4|pages=229–249|doi=10.1080/00364827.1985.10419680|issn=0036-4827}}</ref> and mobility modes.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Posey|first=MH|title=Influence of relative mobilities on the composition of benthic communities|url=http://www.int-res.com/articles/meps/39/m039p099.pdf|journal=Marine Ecology Progress Series|volume=39|pages=99–104|doi=10.3354/meps039099|year=1987|bibcode=1987MEPS...39...99P}}</ref> The most common set of groupings are based on sediment transport and are as follows: * '''Gallery-diffusers''' create complex tube networks within the upper sediment layers and transport sediment through feeding, burrow construction, and general movement throughout their galleries.<ref name=":22">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/47927758|title=Organism-sediment interactions|last=|first=|date=2001|publisher=Published for the Belle W. Baruch Institute for Marine Biology and Coastal Research by the University of South Carolina Press|others=Aller, Josephine Y., Woodin, Sarah Ann, 1945-, Aller, Robert C., Belle W. Baruch Institute for Marine Biology and Coastal Research.|year=|isbn=1570034311|location=Columbia, S.C.|pages=73–86|chapter=A new model of bioturbation for a functional approach to sediment reworking resulting from macrobenthic communities|oclc=47927758}}</ref> Gallery-diffusers are heavily associated with burrowing [[polychaete]]s, such as ''[[Nereis]] diversicolor'' and ''Marenzellaria spp.''<ref name=":30" /><ref name=":22" /> *'''Biodiffusers''' transport sediment particles randomly over short distances as they move through sediments. Animals mostly attributed to this category include [[Bivalvia|bivalves]] such as clams, and [[Amphipoda|amphipod]] species, but can also include larger vertebrates, such as bottom-dwelling fish and rays that feed along the sea floor.<ref name=":30" /><ref name=":22" /> Biodiffusers can be further divided into two subgroups, which include [[epifaunal]] (organisms that live on the surface sediments) biodiffusers and surface biodiffusers.<ref name=":30" /> This subgrouping may also include gallery-diffusers,<ref name=":30" /> reducing the number of functional groups. *'''Upward-conveyors''' are oriented head-down in sediments, where they feed at depth and transport sediment through their guts to the sediment surface.<ref name=":22" /> Major upward-conveyor groups include burrowing [[polychaete]]s like the [[lugworm]], ''Arenicola marina,'' and [[Thalassinidea|thalassinid]] shrimps.<ref name=":24">{{Cite journal|last=Andersen|first=FO|last2=Kristensen|first2=E|date=1991|title=Effects of burrowing macrofauna on organic matter decomposition in coastal marine sediments|url=|journal=Symp. zool. Soc. Lond.|volume=63|pages=69–88|via=researchgate}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Branch|first=G.M.|last2=Pringle|first2=A.|title=The impact of the sand prawn Callianassa kraussi Stebbing on sediment turnover and on bacteria, meiofauna, and benthic microflora|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/0022098187900396|journal=Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology|volume=107|issue=3|pages=219–235|doi=10.1016/0022-0981(87)90039-6|year=1987}}</ref> *'''Downward-conveyor''' species are oriented with their heads towards the [[sediment-water interface]] and defecation occurs at depth.<ref name=":22" /> Their activities transport sediment from the surface to deeper sediment layers as they feed.<ref name=":22" /> Notable downward-conveyors include those in the [[Sipuncula|peanut worm]] family, [[Sipunculidae]].<ref name=":22" />[[File:Arenicola marina 2010.JPG|alt=Lugworm|thumb|185x185px|The lugworm, ''Arenicola marina.'']] * '''Regenerators''' are categorized by their ability to release sediment to the overlying water column, which is then dispersed as they burrow.<ref name=":22" /> After regenerators abandon their burrows, water flow at the sediment surface can push in and collapse the burrow.<ref name=":30" /><ref name=":22" /> Examples of regenerator species include [[Fiddler crab|fiddler]] and [[Ghost crab|ghost]] crabs.<ref name=":30" />
=== Ecological Roles === The evaluation of the ecological role of bioturbators has largely been species-specific.<ref name=":23">{{Cite journal|last=Braeckman|first=U|last2=Provoost|first2=P|last3=Gribsholt|first3=B|last4=Gansbeke|first4=D Van|last5=Middelburg|first5=JJ|last6=Soetaert|first6=K|last7=Vincx|first7=M|last8=Vanaverbeke|first8=J|date=2010-01-28|title=Role of macrofauna functional traits and density in biogeochemical fluxes and bioturbation|url=http://www.int-res.com/abstracts/meps/v399/p173-186/|journal=Marine Ecology Progress Series|language=en|volume=399|pages=173–186|doi=10.3354/meps08336|issn=0171-8630|bibcode=2010MEPS..399..173B}}</ref> However, their ability to transport solutes, such as dissolved oxygen, enhance organic matter decomposition and diagenesis, and alter sediment structure has made them important for the survival and colonization by other macrofaunal and microbial communities.<ref name=":23" />
Microbial communities are greatly influenced by bioturbator activities, as increased transport of more [[Gibbs free energy|energetically favorable]] [[Oxidizing agent|oxidants]], such as oxygen, to typically highly reduced sediments at depth alters the [[Microbial metabolism|microbial metabolic processes]] occurring around burrows.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bertics|first=Victoria resuspension and burrowing modes have variable effects on fluid dynamics at the sediment-water interface.<ref name=":39" /> [[Deposit feeder|Deposit-feeding]] bioturbators may also hamper recruitment by consuming recently settled larvae.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Crowe|first=W. A.|last2=Josefson|first2=A. B.|last3=Svane|first3=I.|date=1987|title=Influence of adult density on recruitment into soft sediments: a short-term in situ sublittoral experiment|journal=Marine Ecology Progress Series|volume=41|issue=1|pages=61–69|doi=10.3354/meps041061|jstor=24827459|bibcode=1987MEPS...41...61C}}</ref>
== Biogeochemical Effects of Bioturbation == Since its onset around 541 million years ago, bioturbation has been responsible for changes in ocean chemistry, primarily through nutrient cycling.<ref name=":15">{{Cite journal|last=Canfield|first=Donald E.|last2=Farquhar|first2=James|date=2009-05-19|title=Animal evolution, bioturbation, and the sulfate concentration of the oceans|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/106/20/8123|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|language=en|volume=106|issue=20|pages=8123–8127|doi=10.1073/pnas.0902037106|issn=0027-8424|pmid=19451639|pmc=2688866|bibcode=2009PNAS..106.8123C}}</ref> Bioturbators played, and continue to play, an important role in nutrient transport across sediments.<ref name=":15" />
For example, bioturbating animals are hypothesized to have affected the cycling of sulfur in the early oceans. According to this hypothesis, bioturbating activities had a large effect on the sulfate concentration in the ocean. Around the Cambrian-Precambrian boundary (541 million years ago), animals begin to mix reduced sulfur from ocean sediments to overlying water causing sulfide to oxidize, which increased the sulfate composition in the ocean. During large extinction events, the sulfate concentration in the ocean was reduced. Although this is difficult to measure directly, seawater sulfur isotope compositions during these times indicates bioturbators influenced the sulfur cycling in the early Earth.
Bioturbators have also altered phosphorus cycling on geologic scales.<ref name=":25">{{cite journal|last1=Dale|first1=A.W|date=2016|title=A model for microbial phosphorus cycling in bioturbated marine sediments: Significance for phosphorus burial in the early Paleozoic|journal=Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta|volume=189|pages=251–268|doi=10.1016/j.gca.2016.05.046|bibcode=2016GeCoA.189..251D}}</ref> Bioturbators mix readily available particulate organic phosphorus (P) deeper into ocean sediment layers which prevents the precipitation of phosphorus [[Mineralization (biology)|(mineralization)]] by increasing the sequestration of phosphorus above normal chemical rates. The sequestration of phosphorus limits oxygen concentrations by decreasing production on a geologic time scale.<ref name=":34" /> This decrease in production results in an overall decrease in oxygen levels, and it has been proposed that the rise of bioturbation corresponds to a decrease in oxygen levels of that time.<ref name=":34">{{cite journal|last1=Boyle|first1=R.A.|date=2014|title=Stabilization of the coupled oxygen and phosphorus cycles by the evolution of bioturbation|volume=7|page=671|doi=10.1038/ngeo2213|journal=Nature Geoscience|bibcode=2014NatGe...7..671B}}</ref> The negative feedback of animals sequestering phosphorus in the sediments and subsequently reducing oxygen concentrations in the environment limits the intensity of bioturbation in this early environment.<ref name=":34" />
Nutrient cycling is still affected by bioturbation in the modern Earth. Some examples in the aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems are below.
=== Aquatic === ==== Terrestrial freshwater ecosystems ==== Important sources of bioturbation in freshwater ecosystems include [[Bottom feeder|benthivorous]] (bottom-dwelling) fish, macroinvertebrates such as worms, insect larvae, crustaceans and molluscs, and seasonal influences from [[Fish migration|anadromous]] (migrating) fish such as salmon. Anadromous fish migrate from the sea into fresh-water rivers and streams to spawn. Macroinvertebrates act as biological pumps for moving material between the sediments and water column, feeding on sediment organic matter and transporting mineralized nutrients into the water column.<ref name=":32">{{Cite journal|last=Adámek|first=Zdeněk|last2=Maršálek|first2=Blahoslav|date=2013-02-01|title=Bioturbation of sediments by benthic macroinvertebrates and fish and its implication for pond ecosystems: a review|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10499-012-9527-3|journal=Aquaculture International|language=en|volume=21|issue=1|pages=1–17|doi=10.1007/s10499-012-9527-3|issn=0967-6120}}</ref> Both benthivorous and anadromous fish can affect ecosystems by decreasing primary production through sediment re-suspension,<ref name=":32" /> the subsequent displacement of benthic primary producers, and recycling nutrients from the sediment back into the water column.<ref name=":33">{{Cite journal|last=Matsuzaki|first=Shin-ichiro S.|last2=Usio|first2=Nisikawa|last3=Takamura|first3=Noriko|last4=Washitani|first4=Izumi|date=2007-01-01|title=Effects of common carp on nutrient dynamics and littoral community composition: roles of excretion and bioturbation|url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/schweiz/fal/2007/00000168/00000001/art00004|journal=Fundamental and Applied Limnology / Archiv f??r Hydrobiologie|volume=168|issue=1|pages=27–38|doi=10.1127/1863-9135/2007/0168-0027}}</ref><ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Holtgrieve|first=Gordon W.|last2=Schindler|first2=Daniel E.|date=2011-02-01|title=Marine-derived nutrients, bioturbation, and ecosystem metabolism: reconsidering the role of salmon in streams|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1890/09-1694.1/abstract|journal=Ecology|language=en|volume=92|issue=2|pages=373–385|doi=10.1890/09-1694.1|issn=1939-9170}}</ref>
==== Lakes and ponds ==== [[File:Chironomidae.jpg|thumb|Chironomid larvae.]] The sediments of lake and pond ecosystems are rich in organic matter, with higher organic matter and nutrient contents in the sediments than in the overlying water.<ref name=":32" /> Nutrient re-regeneration through sediment bioturbation moves nutrients into the water column, thereby enhancing the growth of aquatic plants and phytoplankton ([[primary producers]]).<ref name=":32" /> The major nutrients of interest in this flux are nitrogen and phosphorus, which often limit the levels of primary production in an ecosystem.<ref name=":32" /> Bioturbation increases the flux of mineralized (inorganic) forms of these elements, which can be directly used by primary producers. In addition, bioturbation increases the water column concentrations of nitrogen and phosphorus-containing organic matter, which can then be consumed by fauna and mineralized.<ref name=":32" />
Lake and pond sediments often transition from the aerobic (oxygen containing) character of the overlaying water to the anaerobic (without oxygen) conditions of the lower sediment over sediment depths of only a few millimeters, therefore, even bioturbators of modest size can affect this transition of the chemical characteristics of sediments.<ref name=":32" /> By mixing anaerobic sediments into the water column, bioturbators allow aerobic processes to interact with the re-suspended sediments and the newly exposed bottom sediment surfaces.<ref name=":32" />
Macroinvertebrates including [[Chironomidae|chironomid]] (non-biting midges) larvae and [[Tubifex tubifex|tubificed worms]] (detritus worms) are important agents of bioturbation in these ecosystems and have different effects based on their respective feeding habits. Tubificed worms do not form burrows, they are upward conveyors. Chironomids, on the other hand, form burrows in the sediment, acting as bioirrigators and aerating the sediments and are downward conveyors. This activity, combined with chironomid's respiration within their burrows, decrease available oxygen in the sediment and increase the loss of nitrates through enhanced rates of [[denitrification]].<ref name=":32" />
The increased oxygen input to sediments by macroinvertebrate bioirrigation coupled with bioturbation at the sediment-water interface complicates the total flux of phosphorus . While bioturbation results in a net flux of phosphorus into the water column, the bio-irrigation of the sediments with oxygenated water enhances the adsorption of phosphorus onto iron-oxide compounds, thereby reducing the total flux of phosphorus into the water column.<ref name=":32" />
The presence of macroinvertebrates in sediment can initiate bioturbation due to their status as an important food source for benthivorous fish such as [[Common carp|carp]].<ref name=":32" /> Of the bioturbating, benthivorous fish species, carp in particular are important ecosystem engineers and their foraging and burrowing activities can alter the water quality characteristics of ponds and lakes.<ref name=":33" /> Carp increase water [[turbidity]] by the re-suspension of benthic sediments. This increased turbidity limits light penetration and coupled with increased nutrient flux from the sediment into the water column, inhibits the growth of macrophytes (aquatic plants) favoring the growth of phytoplankton in the surface waters. Surface phytoplankton colonies benefit from both increased suspended nutrients and from recruitment of buried phytoplankton cells released from the sediments by the fish bioturbation.<ref name=":32" /> Macrophyte growth has also been shown to be inhibited by displacement from the bottom sediments due to fish burrowing.<ref name=":33" />
==== Rivers and streams ==== River and stream ecosystems show similar responses to bioturbation activities, with chironomid larvae and tubificid worm macroinvertebrates remaining as important benthic agents of bioturbation.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mermillod-Blondin|first=Florian|last2=Gaudet|first2=Jean-Paul|last3=Gerino|first3=Magali|last4=Desrosiers|first4=Gaston|last5=Jose|first5=Jacques|last6=Châtelliers|first6=Michel Creuzé des|date=2004-07-01|title=Relative influence of bioturbation and predation on organic matter processing in river sediments: a microcosm experiment|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1365-2427.2004.01233.x/abstract|journal=Freshwater Biology|language=en|volume=49|issue=7|pages=895–912|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2427.2004.01233.x|issn=1365-2427}}</ref> These environments are can also be subject to strong season bioturbation effects from anadromous fish.<ref name=":8" />
Salmon function as bioturbators on both gravel to sand-sized sediment and a nutrient scale, by moving and re-working sediments in the construction of redds (gravel depressions or "nests" containing eggs buried under a thin layer of sediment) in rivers and streams<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Gottesfeld|first=AS|last2=Hassan|first2=MA|last3=Tunnicliffe|first3=JF|date=2008|title=Salmon bioturbation and stream process|url=|journal=American Fisheries Society Symposium|volume=65|pages=|via=researchgate}}</ref> and by mobilization of nutrients.<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Buxton|first=Todd H.|last2=Buffington|first2=John M.|last3=Tonina|first3=Daniele|last4=Fremier|first4=Alexander K.|last5=Yager|first5=Elowyn M.|date=2015-04-13|title=Modeling the influence of salmon spawning on hyporheic exchange of marine-derived nutrients in gravel stream beds|url=http://www.nrcresearchpress.com/doi/10.1139/cjfas-2014-0413|journal=Canadian Journal of Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences|volume=72|issue=8|pages=1146–1158|doi=10.1139/cjfas-2014-0413|issn=0706-652X}}</ref> The construction of salmon redds functions to increase the ease of fluid movement ([[hydraulic conductivity]]) and porosity of the stream bed.<ref name=":9" /> In select rivers, if salmon congregate in large enough concentrations in a given area of the river, the total sediment transport from redd construction can equal or exceed the sediment transport from flood events.<ref name=":8" /> The net effect on sediment movement is the downstream transfer of gravel, sand and finer materials and enhancement of water mixing within the river substrate.<ref name=":8" />
The construction of salmon redds increases sediment and nutrient fluxes through the [[hyporheic zone]] (area between surface water and groundwater) of rivers and effects the dispersion and retention of marine derived nutrients (MDN) within the river ecosystem.<ref name=":9" /> MDN are delivered to river and stream ecosystems by the fecal matter of spawning salmon and the decaying carcasses of salmon that have completed spawning and died.<ref name=":9" /> Numerical modeling suggests that residence time of MDN within a salmon spawning reach is inversely proportional to the amount of redd construction within the river.<ref name=":9" /> Measurements of respiration within a salmon-bearing river in Alaska further suggest that salmon bioturbation of the river bed plays a significant role in mobilizing MDN and limiting primary productivity while salmon spawning is active.<ref name=":7" /> The river ecosystem was found to switch from a net [[autotroph]]ic to [[heterotroph]]ic system in response to decreased primary production and increased respiration.<ref name=":7" /> The decreased primary production in this study was attributed to the loss of benthic primary producers who were dislodged due to bioturbation, while increased respiration was thought to be due to increased respiration of organic carbon, also attributed to sediment mobilization from salmon redd construction.<ref name=":7" /> While marine derived nutrients are generally thought to increase productivity in riparian and freshwater ecosystems, several studies have suggested that temporal effects of bioturbation should be considered when characterizing salmon influences on nutrient cycles.<ref name=":7" /><ref name=":9" />
==== Marine environments ==== Major marine bioturbators range from small [[Sediment-dwelling organism|infaunal]] invertebrates to fish and marine mammals.<ref name=":10" /> In most marine sediments, however, they are dominated by small invertebrates, including polychaetes, bivalves, burrowing shrimp, and amphipods.
===== Shallow and Coastal ===== Coastal ecosystems, such as estuaries, are generally highly productive, which results in the accumulation of large quantities of [[detritus]] (organic waste). These large quantities, in addition to typically small sediment grain size and dense populations, make bioturbators important in estuarine respiration.<ref name=":24" /><ref name=":35">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/798834896|title=Interactions between macro- and microorganisms in marine sediments|date=2005|publisher=American Geophysical Union|others=American Geophysical Union.|isbn=9781118665442|location=Washington, D.C.|oclc=798834896}}</ref> Bioturbators enhance the transport of oxygen into sediments through irrigation and increase the surface area of oxygenated sediments through burrow construction.<ref name=":24" /> Bioturbators also transport organic matter deeper into sediments through general reworking activities and production of fecal matter.<ref name=":24" /> This ability to replenish oxygen and other solutes at sediment depth allows for enhanced respiration by both bioturbators as well as the microbial community, thus altering estuarine elemental cycling.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Nitrogen Cycling in Coastal Marine Environments|last=Aller|first=Robert C.|publisher=John Wiley & Sons Ltd|year=1988|isbn=|editor-last=Blackburn|editor-first=T.H.|location=|pages=301–338|chapter=13. Benthic fauna and biogeochemical processes in marine sediments: the role of burrow structures|editor-last2=Sørensen|editor-first2=J.}}</ref> [[File:Marine Nitrogen Cycle.jpg|thumb|325x325px|The marine nitrogen cycle.]] The effects of bioturbation on the nitrogen cycle are well-documented.<ref name=":36">{{Cite journal|last=Kristensen|first=Erik|last2=Jensen|first2=Mikael Hjorth|last3=Andersen|first3=Torben Kjær|title=The impact of polychaete (Nereis virens Sars) burrows on nitrification and nitrate reduction in estuarine sediments|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/0022098185900152|journal=Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology|volume=85|issue=1|pages=75–91|doi=10.1016/0022-0981(85)90015-2|year=1985}}</ref> Coupled denitrification and nitrification are enhanced due to increased oxygen and nitrate delivery to deep sediments and increased surface area across which oxygen and nitrate can be exchanged.<ref name=":36" /> The enhanced nitrification-denitrification coupling contributes to greater removal of biologically available nitrogen in shallow and coastal environments, which can be further enhanced by the excretion of ammonium by bioturbators and other organisms residing in bioturbator burrows.<ref name=":36" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Henriksen|first=K.|last2=Rasmussen|first2=M. B.|last3=Jensen|first3=A.|date=1983|title=Effect of Bioturbation on Microbial Nitrogen Transformations in the Sediment and Fluxes of Ammonium and Nitrate to the Overlaying Water|journal=Ecological Bulletins|issue=35|pages=193–205|doi=10.2307/20112854|jstor=20112854}}</ref> While both nitrification and denitrification are enhanced by bioturbation, the effects of bioturbators on denitrification rates have been found to be greater than that on rates of nitrification, further promoting the removal of biologically available nitrogen.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kristensen|first=Erik|date=1985|title=Oxygen and Inorganic Nitrogen Exchange in a "Nereis virens" (Polychaeta) Bioturbated Sediment-Water System|journal=Journal of Coastal Research|volume=1|issue=2|pages=109–116|doi=10.2307/4297030|jstor=4297030}}</ref> This increased removal of biologically available nitrogen has been suggested to be linked to increased rates of nitrogen fixation in microenvironments within burrows, as indicated by evidence of nitrogen fixation by sulfate-reducing bacteria via the presence of ''nif''H (nitrogenase) genes.<ref name=":3" />
Bioturbation by walrus feeding is a significant source of sediment and biological community structure and nutrient flux in the Bering Sea.<ref name=":26">{{Cite journal|last=Ray|first=G. Carleton|last2=McCormick-Ray|first2=Jerry|last3=Berg|first3=Peter|last4=Epstein|first4=Howard E.|title=Pacific walrus: Benthic bioturbator of Beringia|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0022098105006283|journal=Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology|volume=330|issue=1|pages=403–419|doi=10.1016/j.jembe.2005.12.043|year=2006}}</ref> Walruses feed by digging their muzzles into the sediment and extracting clams through powerful suction.<ref name=":26" /> By digging through the sediment, walruses rapidly release large amounts of organic material and nutrients, especially ammonium, from the sediment to the water column.<ref name=":26" /> Additionally, walrus feeding behavior mixes and oxygenates the sediment and creates pits in the sediment which serve as new habitat structures for invertebrate larvae.<ref name=":26" />

In the [[Baltic Sea]], the invasive ''Marenzelleria'' species of [[Polychaete|polychaete worms]] can burrow to 35-50 centimeters which is deeper than native animals, thereby releasing previously sequestered contaminants.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":0" /> However, bioturbating animals that live in the sediment ([[infauna]]) can also reduce the flux of contaminants to the water column by burying [[Hydrophobe|hydrophobic]] organic contaminants into the sediment.<ref name=":0" /> Burial of uncontaminated particles by bioturbating organisms provides more absorptive surfaces to sequester chemical pollutants in the sediments.<ref name=":2" />
=== Terrestrial === [[File:Camas pocket gopher mounds.JPG|thumb|Pocket gopher mounds |256x256px]] Plants and animals utilize soil for food and shelter, disturbing the upper soil layers and transporting chemically weathered rock called [[saprolite]] from the lower soil depths to the surface.<ref name=":18" /> Terrestrial bioturbation is important in soil production, burial, organic matter content, and downslope transport. Tree roots are sources of [[soil organic matter]], with root growth and stump decay also contributing to soil transport and mixing.<ref name=":18" /> Death and decay of tree roots first delivers organic matter to the soil and then creates voids, decreasing soil density. Tree uprooting causes considerable soil displacement by producing mounds, mixing the soil, or inverting [[Soil profile|vertical sections of soil.]]<ref name=":18" />
Burrowing animals, such as earth worms and small mammals form passageways for air and water transport which changes the soil properties, such as the vertical particle-size distribution, soil [[porosity]], and nutrient content.<ref name=":18" /> Invertebrates that burrow and consume plant detritus help produce an organic-rich topsoil known as the [[soil biomantle]], and thus contribute to the formation of [[Soil horizon|soil horizons.]]<ref name="shaler1891" /> Small mammals such as [[pocket gophers]] also play an important role in the production of soil, possibly with an equal magnitude to abiotic processes.<ref name=":38">{{Cite journal|last=Reichman|first=O.J.|last2=Seabloom|first2=Eric W.|title=The role of pocket gophers as subterranean ecosystem engineers|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0169534701023291|journal=Trends in Ecology & Evolution|volume=17|issue=1|pages=44–49|doi=10.1016/s0169-5347(01)02329-1|year=2002}}</ref> Pocket gophers form above-ground mounds, which moves soil from the lower soil horizons to the surface, exposing minimally weathered rock to surface erosion processes, speeding soil formation.<ref name=":18" /> Pocket gophers are thought to play an important role in the downslope transport of soil, as the soil that forms their mounds is more susceptible to erosion and subsequent transport. Similar to tree root effects, the construction of burrows-even when backfilled- decreases soil density.<ref name=":38" /> The formation of surface mounds also buries surface vegetation, creating nutrient hotspots when the vegetation decomposes, increasing soil organic matter. Due to the high metabolic demands of their burrow-excavating subterranean lifestyle, pocket gophers must consume large amounts of plant material.<ref name=":38" /> Though this has a detrimental effect on individual plants, the net effect of pocket gophers is increased plant growth from their positive effects on soil nutrient content and physical soil properties.<ref name=":38" />
== In the fossil record == [[File:Planolites.jpg|thumb|Planolite fossil]]
=== In the sediment record === Patterns or traces of bioturbation are preserved in [[Lithification|lithified]] rock. The study of such patterns is called [[ichnology]], or the study of "trace fossils", which, in the case of bioturbators, are fossils left behind by digging or burrowing animals. This can be compared to the footprint left behind by these animals. In some cases bioturbation is so pervasive that it completely obliterates [[sedimentary structures]], such as laminated layers or [[cross-bedding]]. Thus, it affects the disciplines of [[sedimentology]] and [[stratigraphy]] within geology. The study of bioturbator ichnofabrics uses the depth of the fossils, the cross-cutting of fossils, and the sharpness (or how well defined) of the fossil<ref name=":16">{{Cite journal|last=Taylor|first=A. M.|last2=Goldring|first2=R.|date=|title=Description and analysis of bioturbation and ichnofabric|url=https://doi.org/10.1144/gsjgs.150.1.0141|journal=Journal of the Geological Society|volume=150|issue=1|pages=141–148|doi=10.1144/gsjgs.150.1.0141|via=|year=1993|bibcode=1993JGSoc.150..141T}}</ref> to assess the activity that occurred in old sediments. Typically the deeper the fossil, the better preserved and well defined the specimen.<ref name=":16" />
Important [[trace fossil]]s from bioturbation have been found in marine sediments from tidal, coastal and deep sea sediments. In addition sand dune, or [[Eolian dust|Eolian]], sediments are important for preserving a wide variety of fossils.<ref name=":29" /> Evidence of bioturbation has been found in deep-sea sediment cores including into long records, although the act extracting the core can disturb the signs of bioturbation, especially at shallower depths.<ref name=":6">{{cite journal|last1=Hertweck|first1=G|last2=Liebezeit|first2=G|title=Bioturbation structures of polychaetes in modern shallow marine environments and their analogues to Chondrites group traces|journal=Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology|date=2007|volume=245|issue=3|pages=382–389|doi=10.1016/j.palaeo.2006.09.001}}</ref> Arthropods, in particular are important to the geologic record of bioturbation of Eolian sediments. Dune records show traces of burrowing animals as far back as the lower Mesozoic (250 Million years ago),<ref name=":29">{{cite journal|last1=Ahlbrandt|first1=T. S.|last2=Andrews|first2=S.|last3=Gwynne|first3=D.T.|title=Bioturbation in eolian deposits|journal=Journal of Sedimentary Research|date=1978|volume=48|issue=3|doi=10.1306/212f7586-2b24-11d7-8648000102c1865d}}</ref> although bioturbation in other sediments has been seen as far back as 550 Ma.<ref name=":25" /><ref name=":34" />
== Mathematical Models == The role of bioturbators in sediment biogeochemistry makes bioturbation a common parameter in sediment biogeochemical models, which are often [[Numerical modeling (geology)|numerical models]] built using [[Ordinary differential equation|ordinary]] and [[partial differential equation]]s.<ref name=":41">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/851842693|title=Diagenetic Models and Their Implementation : Modelling Transport and Reactions in Aquatic Sediments|last=P.|first=Boudreau, Bernard|date=1997|publisher=Springer Berlin Heidelberg|isbn=364264399X|location=Berlin, Heidelberg|oclc=851842693}}</ref> Bioturbation is typically represented as D<sub>B</sub>, or the biodiffusion coefficient, and is described by a [[Diffusion equation|diffusion]] and, sometimes, an [[Advective derivative|advective]] term.<ref name=":41" /> This representation and subsequent variations account for the different modes of mixing by functional groups and bioirrigation that results from them. The biodiffusion coefficient is usually measured using [[radioactive tracer]]s such as Pb<sup>210</sup>,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sharma|first=P.|last2=Gardner|first2=L. R.|last3=Moore|first3=W. S.|last4=Bollinger|first4=M. S.|date=1987-03-01|title=Sedimentation and bioturbation in a salt marsh as revealed by 210Pb, 137Cs, and 7Be studies12|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.4319/lo.1987.32.2.0313/abstract|journal=Limnology and Oceanography|language=en|volume=32|issue=2|pages=313–326|doi=10.4319/lo.1987.32.2.0313|issn=1939-5590|bibcode=1987LimOc..32..313S}}</ref> [[radioisotopes]] from nuclear fallout,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bunzl|first=K|title=Transport of fallout radiocesium in the soil by bioturbation: a random walk model and application to a forest soil with a high abundance of earthworms|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0048969702000141|journal=Science of the Total Environment|volume=293|issue=1–3|pages=191–200|doi=10.1016/s0048-9697(02)00014-1|bibcode=2002ScTEn.293..191B|year=2002}}</ref> introduced particles including glass beads tagged with radioisotopes or inert fluorescent particles,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Solan|first=Martin|last2=Wigham|first2=Benjamin D.|last3=Hudson|first3=Ian R.|last4=Kennedy|first4=Robert|last5=Coulon|first5=Christopher H.|last6=Norling|first6=Karl|last7=Nilsson|first7=Hans C.|last8=Rosenberg|first8=Rutger|date=2004-04-28|title=In situ quantification of bioturbation using time lapse fluorescent sediment profile imaging (f SPI), luminophore tracers and model simulation|url=http://www.int-res.com/abstracts/meps/v271/p1-12/|journal=Marine Ecology Progress Series|volume=271|pages=1–12|doi=10.3354/meps271001|bibcode=2004MEPS..271....1S}}</ref> and chlorophyll a.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gerino|first=M.|last2=Aller|first2=R.C.|last3=Lee|first3=C.|last4=Cochran|first4=J.K.|last5=Aller|first5=J.Y.|last6=Green|first6=M.A.|last7=Hirschberg|first7=D.|title=Comparison of Different Tracers and Methods Used to Quantify Bioturbation During a Spring Bloom: 234-Thorium, Luminophores and Chlorophylla|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0272771497902985|journal=Estuarine, Coastal and Shelf Science|volume=46|issue=4|pages=531–547|doi=10.1006/ecss.1997.0298|year=1998|bibcode=1998ECSS...46..531G}}</ref> Biodiffusion models are then fit to vertical distributions (profiles) of tracers in sediments to provide values for D<sub>B</sub>.<ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|last=Reed|first=Daniel C.|last2=Huang|first2=Katherine|last3=Boudreau|first3=Bernard P.|last4=Meysman|first4=Filip J.R.|title=Steady-state tracer dynamics in a lattice-automaton model of bioturbation|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0016703706002018|journal=Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta|volume=70|issue=23|pages=5855–5867|doi=10.1016/j.gca.2006.03.026|bibcode=2006GeCoA..70.5855R|year=2006}}</ref>
Parameterization of bioturbation, however, can vary, as newer and more complex models can be used to fit tracer profiles. Unlike the standard biodiffusion model, these more complex models, such as expanded versions of the biodiffusion model, random walk, and particle-tracking models, can provide more accuracy, incorporate different modes of sediment transport, and account for more spatial heterogeneity.<ref name=":13" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Aquino|first=Tomás|last2=Roche|first2=Kevin R.|last3=Aubeneau|first3=Antoine|last4=Packman|first4=Aaron I.|last5=Bolster|first5=Diogo|date=2017|title=A Process-Based Model for Bioturbation-Induced Mixing|url=http://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-017-14705-1|journal=Scientific Reports|language=En|volume=7|issue=1|pages=|doi=10.1038/s41598-017-14705-1|issn=2045-2322|via=|bibcode=2017NatSR...714287A}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wheatcroft|first=R. A.|last2=Jumars|first2=P. A.|last3=Smith|first3=C. R.|last4=Nowell|first4=A. R. M.|date=1990-02-01|title=A mechanistic view of the particulate biodiffusion coefficient: Step lengths, rest periods and transport directions|url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/jmr/jmr/1990/00000048/00000001/art00008|journal=Journal of Marine Research|volume=48|issue=1|pages=177–207|doi=10.1357/002224090784984560}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Delmotte|first=Sebastien|last2=Gerino|first2=Magali|last3=Thebault|first3=Jean Marc|last4=Meysman|first4=Filip J. R.|date=2008-03-01|title=Modeling effects of patchiness and biological variability on transport rates within bioturbated sediments|url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/jmr/jmr/2008/00000066/00000002/art00002|journal=Journal of Marine Research|volume=66|issue=2|pages=191–218|doi=10.1357/002224008785837158}}</ref>
